Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge erred in concluding that the applicants did not meet residency requirements
Application_Facts: Applicants had significant absences from Canada and provided incomplete documentation including tax returns, health records, and bank statements with gaps
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Court_Ruling: The court upheld the citizenship judge's decision
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship judge applied legal standards and assessed evidence appropriately
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in the judge's interpretation of residency requirements
Legal_Standard: Applicants must accumulate at least 1,095 days of residence in Canada within 1,460 days before application
Assessment_Factor: Completeness and credibility of submitted documentation
Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision
Credibility_Assessment: Documentation was found to be insufficient and contained gaps affecting credibility
Application_Basis: Residency requirement under Canadian citizenship law
Evidence_Assessed: Gaps in tax, health, and financial records
Governing_Rule: 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within the preceding 1,460 days
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Incomplete documentation failing to prove continuous or sufficient residency
Harm_Assessment: Denial of citizenship due to unmet legal requirements
Cause_Description: Insufficient proof of residency during required period
Evidence_Handling: Submitted documents were reviewed and deemed inadequate to establish residency
Evidence_Issues: Gaps in records, lack of comprehensive evidence of physical presence
Evidence_Assessment: Judge reasonably concluded residency was not proven based on available evidence
Decision_Rationale: Applicants failed to provide sufficient evidence to meet statutory residency requirement
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Commission / Federal Court reviewing judge
